results.title: Beyond Babel. Program 1. Trade
results.creator_credit: Infonation, Sally Westbury, Ron Blythe and Mike Fiddler
results.brief_description: With the advent of the 21st century came the unstoppable global spread of English as the universal language. “Beyond Babel” explores the reasons behind this phenomenal growth through four separate programs: Trade, Culture, Politics, Future. In this first program, we see the effects of globalisation and international trade on such countries as China, India, Africa and South Africa and how the English language has become a link to the outside world for the poorer nations. In recognition of the power of the English language, many non-English speaking countries are teaching English as a second language to their school children in order to help in advancing their careers, particularly in Africa and India. Shows examples of the power of global brands (American), i.e. Coca-Cola, Levis, McDonalds and how English unifies the corporate business on an international level, particularly in the recruitment of staff - all staff, whether in China, India, Africa, are required to speak some level of English. The question is asked, “has English banished nationhood in favour of global branding?”. The dominance of English in the financial markets where words or “mainstream jargon” cross all international boundaries and globalisation equals connectivity, the subject of dependence by world businesses on the lingua franca of international business English is discussed. Narrated by Hugh Quarshie.

results.title: Beyond a reasonable doubt
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Bert Friedlob and Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Guilty beyond a reasonable doubt - such is the incontrovertible law which pardons the innocent and condemns the guilty. But just how fallible is the process of law? To what extent can deceit, prejudice - and the cruel powers of fate - intervene to set a murderer free, or send an innocent man to the electric chair? Dana Andrews plays Tom Carret, a writer who becomes obsessed with the idea of proving that it is possible for a completely innocent man to be found guilty of murder. And when a pretty showgirl is found strangled in a ravine, and no killer can be found, the perfect opportunity presents itself. This dark and chilling drama is the last film Lang made in Hollywood.

results.title: Beyond 2000 Climate in Crisis
results.brief_description: The Greenhouse Effect is the greatest environmental issue to hit the world this century. Its ultimate consequences could be second only to a nuclear war. Created by the Beyond 2000 group, “Climate in Crisis” comprises six segments. In this special report the phenomenon, the Greenhouse Effect, is examined from a global perspective featuring both British and Australian correspondents. Rated: G

results.title: Between wars
results.brief_description: In 1918, Edward Trenbow, a young Australian doctor serving in World War I is assigned to a mental hospital and befriends a German prisoner-of-war, Dr Karl Schneider. From him he learns of the controversial theories of Sigmund Freud but loses interest when moved to a Sydney mental hospital. Stars Corin Redgrave, Arthur Dignam and Judy Morris.

results.title: Between us
results.brief_description: ‘Between us’ is prolific Melbourne filmmaker Bill Mousoulis’ 31st film. Shot in an achingly realistic style, the film is about choices - how people from varying backgrounds find themselves holding back from making decisions that can change their lives. Central to the narrative is Rick (Phillip Dean), a washing machine repairman who thinks there’s more to life than what he’s doing. Through him we encounter Monica and Loretta; one a woman whose living her dream as a singer, the other too afraid to defy her boyfriend and join the workforce. Cast also includes Sharon Rider, Juliet Ward and James Cruickshank.

results.title: Between two wars: twilight of an era (1934-1939)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Nicholas Balla and William Weintraub
results.brief_description: Twilight of an Era examines some of the important events in Canada during the Depression years: the Moose River mine disaster; the great drought on the prairies and the subsequent Prairie Rehabilitation Program; the introduction of a transatlantic air service between Canada and Europe. The film also looks at the major world events that impacted on Canada: the abdication of the king of England; civil war in Spain; Hitler’s rise to power and the death of ten year old Margaret Hayworth aboard the Athenia; Canada’s declaration of war on Germany.

results.title: Between two wars: sunshine and eclipse (1927-1934)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Nicholas Balla and William Weintraub
results.brief_description: Confident, prosperous Canada, expanding in all directions; then the stock market crash of 1929, its sequel the Great Depression, and a nation staggering with poverty and unemployment. But with it all, an optimistic outlook: bargains by mail order; extremes in women’s fashions; political see-sawing; hockey broadcasts by a very youthful Foster Hewitt; the word “quintuplets” in every headline.

results.title: Between two rivers
results.brief_description: Oxford, Stratford-upon-Avon and the Cotswolds form the backcloth of this travelogue. After exploring the history of the university city of Oxford, the film moves to Stratford-upon-Avon where sequences include an excerpt from a production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre, and a visit to Anne Hathaway’s cottage. Music composed and conducted by Muir Mathieson.
